reasons_to_visit.details: Experience Galway's massive St. Patrick's Day celebrations (March 17th). The city hosts one of Ireland's largest and most vibrant parades, street entertainment, ubiquitous traditional music, and a legendary party atmosphere, often spanning several days.
Witness the first signs of spring along the River Corrib and Galway Bay. Daylight hours increase significantly, offering more time to explore the city as nature slowly re-emerges.

March offers fewer crowds at attractions compared to summer (excluding St. Patrick's week). Enjoy better accommodation value and a more relaxed pace for exploring the Latin Quarter, Salthill, or nearby areas.
Check schedules for the Town Hall Theatre or local venues for plays, concerts, or events that often occur in March, providing good indoor entertainment.
Mixed March weather is perfect for diving into Galway's world-famous pubs. Enjoy live music, hearty food, and the warm 'craic', especially lively around St. Patrick's Day.
Explore Galway City Museum, Galway Cathedral, St. Nicholas' Church, the National Aquarium, or browse the city's unique shops when the weather turns wet.

reasons_to_reconsider.details: March in Galway is notoriously unpredictable and often wet and windy due to Atlantic systems. Expect anything from bright sunshine to heavy rain and gales, sometimes all in one day. Pack accordingly!
The week surrounding March 17th is extremely busy in Galway. Pubs are packed, accommodation prices soar, and booking *far* in advance is absolutely essential.
While beautiful, the Connemara landscape will still largely be in its winter state, potentially brown and windswept rather than lush green.
If Easter falls late March, expect increased crowds, potential peak pricing around the holiday weekend, and closures on Good Friday/Easter Monday.

weather.precipitation: Frequent rain and wind remain highly likely (average 90-100mm monthly). Can feel raw and damp. Frost possible inland.
weather.general_tips: Essential packing: high-quality waterproof and windproof jacket, warm layers (fleece, thermals), hat, gloves, scarf, waterproof footwear. Umbrella useful but can struggle in wind.

tourism_level.crowds: Low to Moderate. Generally quiet, allowing for easy exploration of the city centre and attractions.
tourism_level.pricing: Good shoulder season value for accommodation before the St. Patrick's Day surge.
tourism_level.overall_atmosphere: City emerges from winter. Noticeable increase in daylight. Pubs are cozy escapes. Anticipation builds for St. Patrick's Day later in the month.

events_holidays.name: Mother's Day (Ireland & UK)
events_holidays.description: Restaurants and cafes tend to be busier for Sunday lunch/afternoon tea. Book ahead for special meals.
events_holidays.notes: Date differs from US Mother's Day.

events_holidays.name: Six Nations Rugby Finals (Potentially)
events_holidays.description: If the final matches fall here, pubs showing the games (especially Ireland matches) will be very lively and crowded.

unique_experiences.description: Discover the history of Galway and its maritime heritage in this free museum, offering shelter and insight.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Check opening hours (often closed Mondays). Located right beside the Spanish Arch.

unique_experiences.activity: Wander the Latin Quarter & Shop Street
unique_experiences.description: Explore the medieval streets and unique shops (books, crafts, Claddagh rings) with fewer crowds than peak season.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Plenty of cafes and pubs to duck into if rain starts. Enjoy the architecture.

unique_experiences.description: Explore Galway's large medieval parish church, full of history and atmosphere.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Check opening hours. Offers a peaceful indoor experience.

unique_experiences.activity: Enjoy a Trad Session by the Fire
unique_experiences.where: Various Pubs (e.g., Tigh Coili, The Crane Bar, Taaffes)
unique_experiences.description: Seek out a traditional pub known for live Irish music sessions. Enjoy the music and warm atmosphere, often with an open fire.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Check pub schedules for session times (often 9pm+). Arrive early for a seat.

weather.precipitation: Still highly variable. Rain remains frequent, but chances of brighter, longer spells increase. Wind is common.
weather.general_tips: Waterproofs and layers remain essential. Be prepared for rapid weather changes.

tourism_level.crowds: Extremely High around St. Patrick's Day (17th). Parade route and pubs will be packed. Quieter afterwards, unless Easter falls late.
tourism_level.pricing: Peak prices and extremely limited availability around St. Patrick's Day. Book accommodation months, if not a year, in advance. Prices may drop after, subject to Easter timing.
tourism_level.overall_atmosphere: Hugely festive, energetic, and crowded around St. Patrick's Day. A major party atmosphere takes over the city. Quiets down later, unless impacted by Easter.

events_holidays.name: St. Patrick's Festival & Parade
events_holidays.description: Galway hosts one of Ireland's best St. Patrick's Day parades. Expect large crowds, street performers, music, and an immense buzz across the city centre.
events_holidays.notes: Parade day (17th) is exceptionally busy. Secure a viewing spot hours in advance. Check official festival website for full event schedule. Pubs are overflowing.

events_holidays.name: Easter Weekend (if applicable)
events_holidays.description: Good Friday/Easter Monday are public holidays. Potential for increased domestic tourism, closures (shops, some services). Religious observances.
events_holidays.notes: Confirm opening hours. Book accommodation/transport far ahead if dates overlap.

unique_experiences.activity: Witness the Galway St. Patrick's Day Parade
unique_experiences.where: Parade Route through City Centre (usually includes Eyre Square)
unique_experiences.description: Experience the energy and colour of one of Ireland's top St. Patrick's Day parades, featuring community groups, performers, and music.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Arrive *very* early (hours) for a decent view, especially near Eyre Square. Dress warmly and waterproofly. Be prepared for massive crowds.

unique_experiences.activity: Join the Craic in a City Pub on St. Patrick's Day
unique_experiences.where: Any City Centre Pub (esp. Latin Quarter)
unique_experiences.description: Immerse yourself in the legendary atmosphere. Expect live music, singing, green attire, and packed spaces.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Choose a pub and potentially stay put, as moving between packed pubs is hard. Go early. Be patient and enjoy the unique chaos.

unique_experiences.description: On a brighter day after the Paddy's Day rush, take a bracing walk along the famous Prom, enjoying the sea air and views across Galway Bay.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Wrap up well, as it can still be very windy. Kick the wall at the end!

unique_experiences.description: Explore the impressive modern cathedral, offering a peaceful indoor contrast to the potential outdoor weather or festive crowds.
